column1: Memphis is a city along the Mississippi River in southwestern Shelby County
column2: Tennessee
column3: United States. Its 2019 population was 651
column5: making it Tennessee's second-most populous city and the nation's 26th-largest. Greater Memphis is the 42nd-largest metropolitan area in the United States
column6: with a population of 1
column8: 260 in 2017. The city is the anchor of West Tennessee and the greater Mid-South region
column9: which includes portions of neighboring Arkansas
column11: and the Missouri Bootheel. Memphis is the seat of Shelby County
column12: Tennessee's most populous county. One of the more historic and culturally significant cities of the southern United States
column13: Memphis has a wide variety of landscapes and distinct neighborhoods.

column1: The first European explorer to visit the area of present-day Memphis was Spanish conquistador Hernando de Soto in 1541 with his expedition into the New World. The high Chickasaw Bluffs protecting the location from the waters of the Mississippi was then contested by the Spanish
column2: French
column3: and the English as Memphis took shape. Modern Memphis was founded in 1819 by three prominent Americans: John Overton
column4: James Winchester
column5: and future president Andrew Jackson.Memphis grew into one of the largest cities of the Antebellum South as a market for agricultural goods
column6: natural resources like lumber
column7: and the American slave trade. After the American Civil War and the end of slavery
column8: the city experienced even faster growth into the 20th century as it became among the largest world markets for cotton and lumber.

column1: Home to Tennessee's largest African-American population
column2: Memphis played a prominent role in the American civil rights movement and was the site of Martin Luther King Jr.'s 1968 assassination. The city now hosts the National Civil Rights Museum—a Smithsonian affiliate institution. Since the civil rights era
column3: Memphis has become one of the nation's leading commercial centers in transportation and logistics. Its largest employer is the multinational courier corporation FedEx
column4: which maintains its global air hub at Memphis International Airport
column5: making it the second-busiest cargo airport in the world. In addition to being a global air cargo leader
column6: the International Port of Memphis also hosts the fifth-busiest inland water port in the U.S.
column7: with access to the Mississippi River allowing shipments to arrive from around the world for conversion to train and trucking transport throughout the United States
column8: making Memphis a multi-modal hub for trading goods for imports and exports despite its inland location.

column1: Occupying a substantial bluff rising from the Mississippi River
column2: the site of Memphis has been a natural location for human settlement by varying cultures over thousands of years. The area was settled in the first millennium A.D. by people of the Mississippian Culture
column3: who had a network of communities throughout the Mississippi River Valley and its tributaries. They built complexes with large earthwork ceremonial and burial mounds as expressions of their sophisticated culture. The historic Chickasaw Indian tribe
column4: believed to be their descendants
column5: later inhabited the site.French explorers led by René-Robert Cavelier
column6: Sieur de La Salle and Spanish explorer Hernando de Soto encountered the Chickasaw in that area in the 16th century.

column1: The city of Memphis was founded on May 22
column2: 1819 (incorporated December 19
column4: by John Overton
column5: James Winchester and Andrew Jackson. They named it after the ancient capital of Egypt on the Nile River. Memphis developed as a trade and transportation center in the 19th century because of its flood-free location high above the Mississippi River. Located in the low-lying delta region along the river
column6: its outlying areas were developed as cotton plantations
column7: and the city became a major cotton market and brokerage center.

column1: The cotton economy of the antebellum South depended on the forced labor of large numbers of African-American slaves
column2: and Memphis also developed as a major slave market for the domestic slave trade. Through the early 19th century
column3: one million slaves were transported from the Upper South
column4: in a huge forced migration to newly developed plantation areas in the Deep South. Many were transported by steamboats along the Ohio and Mississippi rivers. In 1857
column5: the Memphis and Charleston Railroad was completed
column6: connecting Memphis to the Atlantic coast of South Carolina; it was the only east-west railroad constructed across the southern states before the Civil War. This gave planters and cotton brokers access to the coast for shipping cotton to England

column1: The city's demographics changed dramatically in the 1850s and 1860s under waves of immigration and domestic migration. Due to increased immigration since the 1840s and the Great Famine
column2: ethnic Irish made up 9.9% of the population in 1850
column4: when the total population was 22
column5: 623. They encountered considerable discrimination in the city but by 1860
column6: the Irish constituted most of the police force. They also gained many elected and patronage positions in the Democratic Party city government
column7: and an Irishman was elected mayor before the Civil War. At that time
column8: representatives were elected to the city council from 30 wards. The elite were worried about corruption in this system and that so many saloonkeepers were active in the wards. German immigrants also made this city a destination after the 1848 revolutions; both the Irish and German immigrants were mostly Catholic
column9: adding another element to demographic change in this formerly Protestant city.

column1: Tennessee seceded from the Union in June 1861
column2: and Memphis briefly became a Confederate stronghold. Union ironclad gunboats captured it in the naval Battle of Memphis on June 6
column4: and the city and state were occupied by the Union Army for the duration of the war. Union Army commanders allowed the city to maintain its civil government during most of this period but excluded Confederate veterans from office
column5: which shifted political dynamics in the city as the war went on. As Memphis was used as a Union supply base
column6: associated with nearby Fort Pickering
column7: it continued to prosper economically throughout the war. Meanwhile
column8: Confederate General Nathan Bedford Forrest harassed Union forces in the area.

column1: The war years contributed to additional dramatic changes in city population. The Union Army's presence attracted many fugitive slaves who had escaped from surrounding rural plantations. So many sought protection behind Union lines that the Army set up contraband camps to accommodate them. Memphis's black population increased from 3
column3: when the total population was 22
column5: to nearly 20
column7: with most settling south of the city limits. The white population was also increasing
column8: but not to the same degree. After race riots against the blacks in 1866
column9: thousands left the city. The total population in 1870 was 40
column10: 220; the number of blacks declined to 15

column2: Reconstruction and Democratic control ===

column1: The rapid demographic changes added to the stress of war and occupation and uncertainty about who was in charge
column2: increasing tensions between the Irish policemen and black Union soldiers after the war. In three days of rioting in early May 1866
column3: the Memphis Riots erupted
column4: in which white mobs made up of policemen
column5: firemen
column6: and other mostly ethnic Irish Americans attacked and killed 46 blacks
column7: wounding 75 and injuring 100; raped several women; and destroyed nearly 100 houses while severely damaging churches and schools in South Memphis. Much of the black settlement was left in ruins. Two whites were killed in the riot. Many blacks permanently fled Memphis afterward
column8: especially as the Freedmen's Bureau continued to have difficulty in protecting them. Their population fell to about 15

column1: Historian Barrington Walker suggests that the Irish rioted against blacks because of their relatively recent arrival as immigrants and the uncertain nature of their own claim to "whiteness"; they were trying to separate themselves from blacks in the underclass. The main fighting participants were ethnic Irish
column2: decommissioned black Union soldiers
column3: and newly emancipated African American freedmen. Walker suggests that most of the mob were not in direct economic conflict with the blacks
column4: as by then the Irish had attained better jobs
column5: but were establishing dominance over the freedmen.In Memphis
column6: unlike disturbances in some other cities
column7: ex-Confederate veterans were generally not part of the attacks against blacks. The outrages of the riots in Memphis and a similar one in New Orleans in September (the latter did include Confederate veterans) resulted in Congress's passing the Reconstruction Act and the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.

column2: a series of yellow fever epidemics devastated Memphis
column3: with the disease carried by river passengers along the waterways. During the Yellow Fever Epidemic of 1878
column4: more than 5
column5: 000 people were listed in the official register of deaths between July 26 and November 27. The vast majority died of yellow fever
column6: making the epidemic in the city of 40
column7: 000 one of the most traumatic and severe in urban U.S. history. Within four days of the Memphis Board of Health's declaration of a yellow fever outbreak
column9: 000 residents fled the city. The ensuing panic left the poverty-stricken
column11: and the African-American community at most risk from the epidemic. Those who remained relied on volunteers from religious and physician organizations to tend to the sick. By the end of the year
column13: 000 were confirmed dead in Memphis. The New Orleans health board listed "not less than 4
column17: 000 deaths. The $15 million in losses caused by the epidemic bankrupted Memphis
column18: and as a result its charter was revoked by the state legislature.

column2: Memphis's population of 40
column3: 000 was almost double that of Nashville and Atlanta
column4: and it was the second-largest city in the South after New Orleans. Its population continued to grow after 1870
column5: even when the Panic of 1873 hit the US hard
column6: particularly in the South. The Panic of 1873 resulted in expanding Memphis's underclasses amid the poverty and hardship it wrought
column7: giving further credence to Memphis as a rough
column8: shiftless city. Leading up to the outbreak in 1878
column9: it had suffered two yellow fever epidemics
column12: giving it a reputation as sickly and filthy. It was unheard of for a city with a population as large as Memphis's not to have any waterworks; the city still relied for supplies entirely on collecting water from the river and rain cisterns
column13: and had no way to remove sewage. The combination of a swelling population
column14: especially of lower and working classes
column15: and abysmal health and sanitary conditions made Memphis ripe for a serious epidemic.

column2: an owner of an Italian "snack house"
column3: died of the fever on August 13. Hers was officially reported by the Board of Health
column4: on August 14
column5: as the first case of yellow fever in the city. A massive panic ensued. The same trains and steamboats that brought thousands into Memphis now in five days carried away over 25
column6: 000 Memphians
column7: more than half of the population. On August 23
column8: the Board of Health finally declared a yellow fever epidemic in Memphis
column10: hemorrhaging its population. In July of that year
column11: the city had a population of 47
column15: 000 of them had yellow fever. The only people left in the city were the lower classes

column1: Immediately following the Board of Health's declaration
column2: a Citizen's Relief Committee was formed by Charles G. Fisher. It organized the city into refugee camps. The committee's main priority was to separate the poor from the city and isolate them in refugee camps. The Howard Association
column3: formed specifically for yellow fever epidemics in New Orleans and Memphis
column4: organized nurses and doctors in Memphis and throughout the country. They stayed at the Peabody Hotel
column5: the only hotel to keep its doors open during the epidemic. From there they were assigned to their respective districts. Physicians of the epidemic reported seeing as many as 100 to 150 patients daily.The sisters of St. Mary's Hospital played an important role during the epidemic in caring for the lower classes. Already supporting a girls' school and church orphanage
column6: the sisters of St. Mary's also sought to provide care for the Canfield Asylum
column7: a home for black children. Each day
column8: they alternated caring for the orphans at St. Mary's
column9: delivering children to the Canfield Asylum
column10: and taking soup and medicine on house calls to patients. Between September 9 and October 4
column11: Sister Constance and three other nuns fell victim to the epidemic and died. They later became known as the Martyrs of Memphis.At long last
column13: a killing frost struck. The city sent out word to Memphians scattered all over the country to come home. Though yellow fever cases were recorded in the pages of Elmwood Cemetery's burial record as late as February 29
column15: the epidemic seemed quieted. The Board of Health declared the epidemic
column17: 000 deaths and financial losses of nearly $200 million
column19: a general citizen's meeting was called at the Greenlaw Opera House to offer thanks to those who had stayed behind to serve
column20: of whom many died. Over the next year property tax revenues collapsed
column21: and the city could not make payments on its municipal debts. As a result
column22: Memphis temporarily lost its city charter and was reclassified by the state legislature as a Taxing District from 1878 to 1893. But a new era of sanitation was developed in the city
column23: a new municipal government in 1879 helped form the first regional health organization
column24: and during the 1880s Memphis led the nation in sanitary reform and improvements.Perhaps the most significant effect of the yellow fever on Memphis was in demographic changes. Nearly all of Memphis's upper and middle classes vanished
column25: depriving the city of its general leadership and class structure that dictated everyday life
column26: similar to other large Southern cities such as New Orleans
column29: the poorer whites and blacks fundamentally made up the city and played the greatest role in rebuilding it. The epidemic had resulted in Memphis being a less cosmopolitan place
column30: with an economy that served the cotton trade and a population drawn increasingly from poor white and black Southerners.

column2: resulting in opponents of the D. P. Hadden faction working to deprive them of votes by disenfranchising blacks. The state had enacted several laws
column3: including the requirement of poll taxes
column4: that served to disenfranchise many blacks. Although political party factions in the future sometimes paid poll taxes to enable blacks to vote
column5: African Americans lost their last positions on the city council in this election and were forced out of the police force. (They did not recover the ability to exercise the franchise until after passage of civil rights legislation in the mid-1960s.) Historian L. B. Wrenn suggests the heightened political hostility of the Democratic contest and related social tensions contributed to a white mob lynching three black grocers in Memphis in 1892.Journalist Ida B. Wells of Memphis investigated the lynchings
column6: as one of the men killed was a friend of hers. She demonstrated that these and other lynchings were more often due to economic and social competition than any criminal offenses by black men. Her findings were considered so controversial and aroused so much anger that she was forced to move away from the city. But she continued to investigate and publish the abuses of lynching.Businessmen were eager to increase city population after the losses of 1878–79
column7: and supported annexation of new areas to the city; this was passed in 1890 before the census. The annexation measure was finally approved by the state legislature through a compromise achieved with real estate magnates
column8: and the area annexed was slightly smaller than first proposed.In 1893 the city was rechartered with home rule
column9: which restored its ability to enact taxes. The state legislature established a cap rate. Although commission government was retained and enlarged to five commissioners
column10: Democratic politicians regained control from the business elite. The commission form of government was believed effective in getting things done
column11: but because all positions were elected at-large
column12: requiring them to gain majority votes
column13: this practice reduced representation by candidates representing significant minority political interests.

column2: Memphis developed as the world's largest spot cotton market and the world's largest hardwood lumber market
column3: both commodity products of the Mississippi Delta. Into the 1950s
column4: it was the world's largest mule market. Attracting workers from rural areas as well as new immigrants
column5: from 1900 to 1950 the city increased nearly fourfold in population
column6: from 102
column9: Memphis was a place of machine politics under the direction of E. H. "Boss" Crump. He gained a state law in 1911 to establish a small commission to manage the city. The city retained a form of commission government until 1967 and patronage flourished under Crump. Per the publisher's summary of L.B. Wrenn's study of the period
column10: "This centralization of political power in a small commission aided the efficient transaction of municipal business
column11: but the public policies that resulted from it tended to benefit upper-class Memphians while neglecting the less affluent residents and neighborhoods." The city installed a revolutionary sewer system and upgraded sanitation and drainage to prevent another epidemic. Pure water from an artesian well was discovered in the 1880s
column12: securing the city's water supply. The commissioners developed an extensive network of parks and public works as part of the national City Beautiful movement
column13: but did not encourage heavy industry
column14: which might have provided substantial employment for the working-class population. The lack of representation in city government resulted in the poor and minorities being underrepresented. The majority controlled the election of all the at-large positions.Memphis did not become a home rule city until 1963
column15: although the state legislature had amended the constitution in 1953 to provide home rule for cities and counties. Before that
column16: the city had to get state bills approved in order to change its charter and for other policies and programs. Since 1963
column17: it can change the charter by popular approval of the electorate.During the 1960s
column18: the city was at the center of the Civil Rights Movement
column19: as its large African-American population had been affected by state segregation practices and disenfranchisement in the early 20th century. African-American residents drew from the civil rights movement to improve their lives. In 1968
column20: the Memphis sanitation strike began for living wages and better working conditions; the workers were overwhelmingly African American. They marched to gain public awareness and support for their plight: the danger of their work
column21: and the struggles to support families with their low pay. Their drive for better pay had been met with resistance by the city government.

column1: In recent years the City has decided to de-annex some of its territory.  Its is currently going through a 3 phase process to de-annex 5 areas within the city limits which will return to being part of unincorporated Shelby County.  The first phase of de-annexation occurred on January 1
column2: 2020 when the Eads area and River Bottoms areas of the city returned to county jurisdiction.  As a result Shelby County Sheriff are responsible for patrolling these former parts of the city of Memphis.  It is estimated that this first phase of the de-annexation process will reduce the size of city by 5%
column3: with a reduction in the city population by 0.03%.   The following 2 phases will have a much more significant impact.

column1: Memphis has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa
column2: Trewartha Cf)
column3: with four distinct seasons
column4: and is located in USDA Plant Hardiness Zone 8a in downtown
column5: cooling to 7b for much of the surrounding region. Winter weather comes alternately from the upper Great Plains and the Gulf of Mexico
column6: which can lead to drastic swings in temperature. Summer weather may come from Texas (very hot and humid) or the Gulf (hot and very humid). July has a daily average temperature of 82.7 °F (28.2 °C)
column7: with high levels of humidity due to moisture encroaching from the Gulf of Mexico. Afternoon and evening thunderstorms are frequent during summer
column9: lasting no longer than an hour. Early autumn is pleasantly drier and mild
column10: but can be hot until late October. Late autumn is rainy and cooler; precipitation peaks again in November and December. Winters are mild to chilly
column11: with a January daily average temperature of 41.2 °F (5.1 °C). Snow occurs sporadically in winter
column12: with an average seasonal snowfall of 3.9 inches (9.9 cm). Ice storms and freezing rain pose greater danger
column13: as they can often pull tree limbs down on power lines and make driving hazardous. Severe thunderstorms can occur at any time of the year though mainly during the spring months. Large hail
column15: flooding and frequent lightning can accompany these storms. Some storms spawn tornadoes.

column1: The city's central geographic location has been strategic to its business development. Located on the Mississippi River and intersected by five major freight railroads and two Interstate Highways
column2: I-40 and I-55
column3: Memphis is ideally located for commerce in the transportation and shipping industry. Its access by water was key to its initial development
column4: with steamboats plying the Mississippi river. Railroad construction strengthened its connection to other markets to the east and west.

column2: Memphis adopted a mayor-council form of government
column3: with 13 City Council members
column4: six elected at-large from throughout the city and seven elected from geographic districts. Following passage of the Voting Rights Act of 1965
column5: civil rights activists challenged the at-large is electoral system in court because it made it more difficult for the minority to elect candidates of their choice; at-large voting favored candidates who could command a majority across the city. In 1995
column6: the city adopted a new plan. The 13 Council positions are elected from nine geographic districts: seven are single-member districts and two elect three members each.

column1: Jim Strickland is the city's current mayor
column2: elected on October 8
column3: 2015. He is a former Memphis city councilman. The previous mayor of the city of Memphis was A C Wharton.

column2: regional discussions have recurred on the concept of consolidating unincorporated Shelby County and Memphis into a metropolitan government
column3: as Nashville-Davidson County did in 1963. Consolidation was a referendum item on the 2010 ballots in both the city of Memphis and Shelby County
column4: under the state law for dual-voting on such measures. The referendum was controversial in both jurisdictions. Black leaders
column5: including then-Shelby County Commissioner Joe Ford and national civil rights leader Al Sharpton
column6: opposed the consolidation. According to the plaintiffs' expert
column8: these leaders "tried to turn that referendum into a civil rights issue
column9: suggesting that for blacks to vote for consolidation was to give up hard-won civil rights victories of the past".In October 2010 before the vote
column10: eight Shelby County citizens had filed a lawsuit in federal court against the state and the Shelby County Elections Commission against the dual-voting requirement. Plaintiffs argued that total votes for the referendum should have been counted together
column11: rather than as separate elections. City voters narrowly supported the measure for consolidation with 50.8% in favor; county voters overwhelmingly voted against the measure with 85% against. The state argued that with the election decided
column13: but the federal court disagreed.By late 2013
column15: both sides were trying to disqualify the other's experts
column16: in discussions of whether regional voting revealed racial polarization
column17: and whether voting on the referendum demonstrated racial bloc voting. "The experts for both sides have clashed on whether racial bloc voting is inevitable in local elections and whether that would require some kind of court remedy."The defendants' expert
column19: did not think that polarized voting as revealed for political candidates meant that "African-American voters and white voters have polarized interests when it comes to referendum choices on government administration
column21: service provision and other policy questions." He noted
column22: "In the absence of distinct political interests that create polarized blocs of referendum voters defined by race
column23: there is no cohesive racial minority voting interest that can be diluted by a referendum."In 2014
column24: the federal district court dismissed the lawsuit
column25: on the grounds that the referendum would have failed when both jurisdictions' votes were counted together. (In total voting
column26: 64% of voters opposed the consolidation.) In the last week of December 2014
column27: the U.S. Sixth District Court of Appeals upheld that decision
column30: the referendum for consolidation did not pass and would not have passed even if there had been no dual-majority vote requirement (with the vote counts combined)."Before the referendum
column31: the decision was made by the city and county to exclude public school management and operations from the proposed consolidation. As noted below
column32: in 2011 the Memphis city council voted to dissolve its city school board and consolidate with the Shelby County School System
column33: without the collaboration or agreement of Shelby County. The city had authority for this action under Tennessee state laws that differentiate between city and county powers.

column4: effectively merging it with the Shelby County School District. After issues with state law and court challenges
column5: the merger took effect the start of the 2013–14 school year. In Shelby County
column6: six incorporated cities voted to establish separate school systems in 2013.

column1: A large volume of railroad freight moves through Memphis

column5: St. Louis

column2: Memphis had two major passenger railroad stations
column3: which made the city a regional hub for trains coming from the north
column4: east
column5: south and west. After passenger railroad service declined heavily through the middle of the 20th century
column6: the Memphis Union Station was demolished in 1969. The Memphis Central Station was eventually renovated
column7: and it still serves the city.  The only inter-city passenger railroad service to Memphis is the daily City of New Orleans train
column9: which has one train northbound and one train southbound each day between Chicago and New Orleans.

column1: Memphis International Airport is the global "SuperHub" of FedEx Express
column2: and has the second largest cargo operations by volume of any airport worldwide
column3: surpassed only by Hong Kong International Airport.Memphis International ranks as the 41st busiest passenger airport in the US and served as a hub for Northwest Airlines (later Delta Air Lines) until September 3
column4: 2013. and had 4.39 million boarding passengers (enplanements) in 2011
column5: an 11.9% decrease over the previous year. Delta has reduced its flights at Memphis by approximately 65% since its 2008 merger with Northwest Airlines and operates an average of 30 daily flights as of December 2013
column6: with two international destinations (Cancún - seasonally; Toronto year-round). Delta Air Lines announced the closing of its Memphis pilot and crew base in 2012. Other airlines providing passenger service are: Southwest Airlines; American Airlines; United Airlines; Allegiant; Frontier; Air Canada; and Southern Vacations Express.There are also general aviation airports in the Memphis Metropolitan Area
column8: located at the former Naval Air Station in Millington

column1: Memphis has the second-busiest cargo port on the Mississippi River
column2: which is also the fourth-busiest inland port in the United States. The International Port of Memphis covers both the Tennessee and Arkansas sides of the Mississippi River from river mile 725 (km 1167) to mile 740 (km 1191). A focal point of the river port is the industrial park on President's Island
column3: just south of Downtown Memphis.

column1: Four railroad and highway bridges cross the Mississippi River at Memphis. In order of their opening years
column2: these are the Frisco Bridge (1892
column3: single-track rail)
column4: the Harahan Bridge (1916
column5: a road-rail bridge until 1949
column6: currently carries double-track rail)
column9: and the Hernando de Soto Bridge (Interstate 40
column10: 1973). A bicycle/pedestrian walkway opened along the Harahan Bridge in late 2016

column1: Memphis's primary utility provider is the Memphis Light
column2: Gas and Water Division (MLGW). This is the largest three-service municipal utility in the United States
column3: providing electricity
column4: natural gas
column5: and pure water service to all residents of Shelby County. Prior to that
column6: Memphis was served by two primary electric companies
column7: which were merged into the Memphis Power Company.The City of Memphis bought the private company in 1939 to form MLGW
column8: which was an early customer of electricity from the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). In 1954 the Dixon-Yates contract was proposed to make more power available to the city from the TVA
column9: but the contract was cancelled; it had been an issue for the Democrats in the 1954 Congressional elections.

column1: MLGW still buys most of its power from TVA
column2: and the company pumps its own fresh water from the Memphis Aquifer
column3: using more than 180 water wells.

column1: The Memphis and Shelby County region supports numerous hospitals
column2: including the Methodist and Baptist Memorial health systems
column3: two of the largest private hospitals in the country.

column2: the largest healthcare provider in the Memphis region and the fourth largest employer as of 2018
column3: operates seven hospitals and several rural clinics. Methodist Healthcare operates
column4: among others
column5: the Le Bonheur Children's Hospital
column6: which offers primary level 1 pediatric trauma care
column7: as well as a nationally recognized pediatric brain tumor program.

column1: Baptist Memorial Healthcare operates fifteen hospitals (three in Memphis)
column2: including Baptist Memorial Hospital
column3: and with a merger in 2018 became the largest healthcare system in the mid-South. According to Health Care Market Guide's annual studies
column4: Mid-Southerners have named Baptist Memorial their "preferred hospital choice for quality".

column1: The St. Jude Children's Research Hospital
column2: leading pediatric treatment and research facility focused on children's catastrophic diseases
column3: resides in Memphis. The institution was conceived and built by entertainer Danny Thomas in 1962 as a tribute to St. Jude Thaddeus
column4: patron saint of impossible
column5: hopeless
column6: and difficult causes.

column1: Memphis is also home to Regional One Healthcare
column2: which is locally referred to as "The Med". In recent years
column3: the hospital has experienced severe funding difficulties that nearly led to a reduction or elimination of emergency room services. In July 2010
column4: The Med received approximately $40.6 million in federal and local funding to keep the Elvis Presley Trauma Center operational.

column1: Memphis is home to Delta Medical Center of Memphis
column2: which is the only employee-owned medical facility in North America.

column1: Individual health insurance marketplace insurers are limited
column2: with Bright Health and Cigna offering coverage in the area.
